CIRCULAR  11  /  1998 
 
 
SUB: SECURITY PROCEDURE FOR CARGO 
 
 
In order to prevent weapons, explosives, explosive devices or any other dangerous devices 
which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference, the carriage or bearing of 
which is not authorized, from being introduced by means whatsoever, in the cargo 
consignments on board an aircraft engaged in civil aviation either in a passenger flight or a 
cargo freighter, any one of the following three security measures prescribed by the Bureau of 
Civil Aviation Security (BCAS) shall be strictly followed by air operators:- 
 
(i) 
Cooling off for 24 hours 
(ii) 
X-ray screening. 
(iii) 
Physical checking 
 
2. 
After security check of the cargo consignments, security sticker as per the specimen 
given below shall be pasted / affixed by the security staff of air operator each cargo 
consignment / baggage. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
3. 
The security measures ( any of the three mentioned in para 1 above) shall be 
specifically indicated in the cargo manifest against each cargo consignment. 
 
4. 
The cargo consignment, when taken on airside for loading into the aircraft, shall be 
accompanied with cargo manifest. 
 
5. 
Airport security staff deployed on entry point of the airside shall check / ensure the 
following security procedures: - 
 
(i) 
Security sticker pasted on the cargo consignment. 
(ii) 
Cargo manifest 
(iii) 
Access control of persons / vehicles 
 
6. 
Before cargo is loaded into the aircraft, air operators security, staff shall ensure that 
no cargo consignment is allowed unless it has passed through the prescribed security control.

2:
The cargo manifest shall be signed by the airlines security staff on the apron in token of the 
above process having followed by them. 
 
7. 
The air operators operating from the airports in India shall incorporate these 
instructions in their security manual and confirm to the BCAS about the same. 
 
 
The above directions are issued under Section 5A of the Aircraft Act, 1934.
